Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Hindmarsh) (12.32 p.m.)I return to amendment No. 13. Overnight I have had a chance to have a look at the minister's comments on the amendment and I say again how disappointed I am in the approach the minister has taken to this amendment. I also refer the minister to a radio interview that took place last night on 3LO on this very amendment. I would like to quote to the minister what was said by the Aboriginal person who has a regular time spot on 3LO on Monday nights in reference toMr Tickner-Who was this?

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: It was an ATSIC councillor. The minister might like to look up which particular ATSIC councillor. Mr TIckner interjecting

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: The minister is asking questions across the table which I would Orders prefer not to answer at this time, but I would be very happy to talk to the minister privately. If the minister wishes to know, the name of the counciIIor is Sharon Firebrace. The interview was about the indigenous land fund. In reply to a question about the amendment. we are discussing today, the amendment which the minister said had no support from Aboriginal people, Sharon said, 'It is vital that the bill must have this amendment in it.' So much for this minister claiming that nobody in the Aboriginal community wants these amendments. What the minister means is that the people he has talked to and the people he is getting to act on his behalf do not want this amendment. May I say how disappointed I was in the minister's trying to raise controversy over these amendments when on Sunday he sent to the press his own press release calling for the total support of the coalition on this fund and at the same time orchestrated several Aboriginal groups to send almost identical press releases. What does this say about the minister's approach to this amendment? Does the minister really want to set Aboriginal person against Aboriginal person, saying that these Aboriginal people support the government and these Aboriginal people support the opposition? I say to the minister: if that is the sort of game he really wants to play, it is not in the interests of the Aboriginal people and it is not in the interests of the wider Australian community, which is looking for reconciliation on this issue, which genuinely wants reconciliation and which does not want to see the government playing politics at the expense of the Aboriginal community. I turn to some of the quite interesting points the minister raised in his speech yesterday. He said: ... the coalition again seeks to fetter, constrain and restrict the board of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Yet it was this very minister who, when the coalition tried to widen the debate on this issue, said that we were acting against the interests of Aboriginal people. When the coalition put forward an amendment which would widen the powers of the Indigenous Land Corporation, what did the minister say? The minister said, 'You can't do this.' But on this amendment, the minister accuses us of trying to fetter the ILC. So what is an argument from the minister on one of these amendments turns out to be an opposite argument on another amendment. I tum to the second of the minister's arguments. Yesterday, he said: Conversely, it may be that there are areas which are owned under native title and can be proven before the Native Title Tribunal which are of great cultural significance, but which may be of relatively little economic development potential for that community. (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I think this amendment indicates better than any other the nature of the fraud that is involved in the amendments generally that are being moved to this legislation. I refer to a comment that was made by Mike Seccombe in the Sydney Morning Herald a few days ago. He said: The National Party opposes the whole idea that is, of the land fundSo do a lot of the Liberal Right. But to try to maintain some pretence of progressiveness, the Libs are persevering with the fiction that they only to amend it. That is, of course, the objective of the opposition in this matter. As I have said, this particular amendment, better than any of the others, gives evidence of that. It refers to the need to give priority in the purchase of certain land, the need to ensure that certain land is not acquired. That reflects in the first place quite a clear lack of confidence in the proposed Indigenous Land Corporation and the responsibilities that the land corporation will have in fulfilling its tasks under that legislation. But even more important is the last reference, to the need to give the upgrading of Aboriginal pastoral property priority. That is a completely different issue, as the opposition well knows. This legislation is concerned with setting up a fund to make it possible for land to be purchased for those Aboriginal people who have been so dispossessed that they can no longer now indicate or prove any continuing association with the land on which they currently live or any land with which they may have had some previous relationship over the last 60,000 years. That is the purpose of this legislation. I suppose one would almost feel excused in showing some sympathy for the opposition, knowing the very serious disability that it operates under in connection with these amendments. The most serious disability is the fact that the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) is the shadow minister. We well recall the fiasco just recently when, in connection with issues of this kind, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) had a tour through the Northern Territory. He took with him the shadow minister to act as his adviser. The tour turned into a fiasco and that had the effect of turning the Leader of the Opposition into a figure of ridicule as far as Australia was concerned. It was also this shadow minister who bravely asserted in connection with this issue and this legislation, after she was appointed as shadow minister, that she would be supporting the land fund and she would swing the opposition. They swung her. The shadow minister was soon pulled into line by the Leader of the Opposition. She want went to water. I said yesterday that there was a possibility of her, depending upon the elements of goodwill on the part of the opposition, being able to carry the opposition on this matter. She has shown no courage and no competence. She has become a joke as far as her responsibilities are concerned. Yesterday, when we had a group of national Aboriginal Australian leaders sitting in the gallery, she deliberately offended them. One of them was the Deputy Chairperson of ATSIC, Charles Perkins. The reason she offended and insulted the people in the gallery-they were in a position where they could not respond-was that the minister quite courteously acknowledged their presence with a smile. She used that as an opportunity to insult and offend them. She has no more likelihood of surviving in her position than the Leader of the Opposition does. She is incompetent. She is a failure. The best thing for her to do is to save herself and the opposition any further embarrassment by resigning from her shadow portfolio.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Hindmarsh) (12.41 p.m.)I think the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) was offended yesterday when I said that he had passed his use-by date. We have had some sort of reaction by the honourable member for Charlton. I am sorry that he was offended. I am glad that he got to his feet because, in doing so, he has supported our amendment. It seems that he is a little confused, but even in his confusion we are grateful for his support of our amendment. This fund is meant for people who have been dispossessed and who cannot claim under native title. I thank him for his support. He is a little confused in that he does not realise that the government's own bill directs funds to the upgrading and maintenance of properties. In questioning that, he is questioning his own bill. The honourable member keeps saying that we are opposed to the land fund bill, which shows that he has not followed the debate. I refer him to the speech of his own Prime Minister (Mr Keating)-I quoted this yesterday but I will quote it again-in which he says: In the event, the veracity of the opposition's claims of concern for indigenous people will be tested by two events-the vote on the second reading in the House of Representatives ... What did the coalition do when voting on the motion for the second reading? There were no dissenting votes, which showed our support at the second reading stage. If the honourable member wishes to come into this House and enter the debate, first of all, he should read his own government's bill and, secondly, he should follow the debate to see what has been said by the minister and the Prime Minister. If he did so, he would not continue to make such an absolute fool of himself.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: It is important for us to understand the motivation behind amendments of this kind so that we can better assess the value which they mayor may not contribute to the legislation finally. The government has made it clear that it does not and will not accept these amendments. To a very large extent, this exercise must involve, as it does, a filibuster by the opposition in an attempt to ensure that the legislation is delayed for as long as possible. This bill will pass through this chamber as soon as we have disposed of these amendments, as the opposition knows. It will then go to the Senate. It is the intention of the opposition in the Senate to refer the bill, as it has said, to a Senate select committee for. consideration, despite the fact that for hours and days this chamber has given detailed consideration to the proposed amendments which the opposition has brought forward. There is one other point I want to make in connection with this matter: the legislation provides for funds to be made available for the purchase of land, under the provisions of this legislation, 30 days after royal assent. Let that not go unnoticed: 30 days after the legislation is given assent the funds will be made available; so that for every day the opposition continues to delay this legislation the funds will not be available and those most seriously dispossessed Aboriginal people who would benefit from the application of this legislation will not be given an opportunity to do so. I think it is relevant as well for us to recent acknowledge the fact that the shadow minister has found it necessary to have with her all the time the member for Barker (Mr MCLachlan). She is supposed to be the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs; she is supposed to be able to act as an adviser to the opposition. But she has had her hand held by the honourable member for Barker on every occasion that we have given consideration to this matter. The honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) is one of the best informed members of the opposition in connection with Aboriginal affairs. He is one of the most genuine and committed; and he is a former shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. It is the honourable member for Aston who, in connection with these amendments, should be at the dispatch box looking after the interests of the opposition. He would do it with some level of competence.

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I notice that the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has accused us of delaying procedures here. In fact, he has spoken on this issue more often than even his minister. Mr Robert Brown-Not so.

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: We will add them up. Mr Robert Brown-I have interjected more frequently.

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: No-one, I suggest, has raised the decibel level here more than the member for Charlton has. I suggest that he take a leaf out of the Speaker's book; he has now reduced his decibel level and I am hoping that that will be a permanent change in this chamber. I will raise two points. One is that the member for Charlton said the last time we were in this chamber on this matter-and said again today-that this land fund was supposed to be for those Aboriginals who were so dispossessed of their previous land that they were not able to acquire title under the Native Title Act. Not only did he say that but it was stated on page 3 of the preamble to the Native Title Bill. It says: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land. In other words, when we put in an amendment which says exactly that, no matter what, those opposite will disagree with it. The member for Charlton said that just a minute ago. He said, 'No matter what it is, we the government are going to oppose it.' It does not matter what amendment we put here-the government will oppose it. We know why the government could not put this clause in the bill. The minister, the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) were telling us that all these claims under the Native Title Act would be quickly fixed. The fact is that if we do not know who is going to get native title, because the claims will go on and on with court case after court case and decision after decision, we cannot acquire land under an acquisition fund for those people who are not going to get some benefit from native title. The government had to change its whole tack because its arrangements under the Native Title Act have turned out to be hopelessly inefficient and are not going to work. So it is terrible hypocrisy of this government to say that it is against the first clause of our amendment-that is exactly what it said in the Native Title Bill explanatory memorandum. I will read it again. It states: Recognising that many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be unable to secure native title and to benefit directly from the High Court decision, the Bill establishes a National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. Clause 192 of the bill was principally devoted to the acquisition of land. Of course, when we put forward that simple clause, in almost your own words, you will oppose it because you will oppose anything we suggest, however good it is or however much you might in fact have approved of it in times past.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (12.50 p.m.)-I understand that this is one of the amendments the coalition is going to call a division on. Therefore, it is appropriate that I respond to at least some of the things that have been said in the course of this debate. I rights and must say, we have had a very revealing contribution from the honourable member for Barker (Mr MCLachlan). In that contribution we saw yet again the strident opposition of a very senior coalition front bench member to the Native Title Act. The rest of the world knows that those in the coalition who determine Aboriginal affairs policy are the people who have contributed very much to this debate. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is well known for his sympathy for the Aboriginal cause. The member for Barker, only a matter of four months ago, went on the public record and gave an ironclad commitment not only that the Native Title Act would be repealed but also that the land fund bill would not be supported. The member for Barker cannot deny that. He has always been opposed to the land fund and he got his way because the coalition has adopted a policy that simply leaves the government no alternative but to proceed with its bill. These are not genuine amendments. They are not amendments that have been put forward by the coalition in any attempt to improve the bill. Let me record the history of the government's attempts to get the land fund package right as a negotiated outcome. Firstly, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) wrote to the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), a matter of four or five months ago. The Prime Minister also wrote to the state and territory leaders, to the National Farmers Federation and to other industry bodies because he, like the of the government, wanted to get the best bill. Despite that letter to the coalition, no response was forthcoming. Again, when the legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives not two weeks ago, not three weeks ago, not a month ago, but two months ago, the Prime Minister wrote again to the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and invited him, in a spirit of goodwill and cross-party cooperation, to put forward proposals for improvements to the bill. Not only was there not a reply over that period of weeks and months, but it was in fact at the eleventh hour, when the bill be debated in the House of Representatives, that members in this chamber were seeking to get information about the coalition amendments. What we got was a cobbled together version of some amendments that were first described by the coalition as a refocus of the bill with significant amendments. If we search the public record, we will see that that is the case. We now find that on the ABC radio program Australia Talks Back, the shadow minister described the amendments as 'some slight changes'. Only one week ago she described the amendments in their totality as 'very slight'. Given that, by the coalition's mission, these are very slight amendments, will the coalition support the bill when it comes to a vote in the House of Representatives? The available information we have suggests that at least some members of the coalition, including members of the front-bench, would like to do just that. This morning's Daily Telegraph Mirror reports: Several senior Liberal MPs are "angry and dismayed" over Opposition Leader Alexander Downer's staunch refusal to back the Aboriginal land fund. Well may they be angry and dismayed! Twenty years ago in this chamber Sir Billy Snedden-and before him Sir William MCMahon-speaking for the coalition of yesteryear was prepared to support land acquisition by Aboriginal people. In 1974 a fund was established with the rest unanimous support of this parliament. That fund was the fledgling effort of the Commonwealth to address the position and rights of dispossessed people. Twenty years on we find that the coalition has turned back the clock: it will not support the government's bill. These so-called amendments are just a smokescreen to hide that strident opposition. When the legislation goes to the Senate there will be more amendments and an attempt to establish a Senate inquiry-every trick in the book will be used to try to stop this legislation. (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Barker) (12.55 p.m.)I really cannot let that ridiculous tirade pass was to without making a comment or two. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) is saying that we, on this side of the House, are standing in the way of land acquisition for Aboriginals. I think the minister comes from New South Wales. I do not recall how much land has been provided to Aboriginals by successive New South Wales governments, but my guess is that it is of the order of the size of one sheep station. Twenty per cent of the land of my state has been provided for Aboriginals, and more will eventuate. That land has been provided by the state government. The hypocrisy that comes out of Victoria own adand New South Wales on this matter of looking after Aboriginals is starting to annoy me somewhat. The state from which the minister emanates has not provided land worth a damn to Aboriginals-and Victoria has provided less. One cannot even measure it; it is not statistically measurable on any piece of paper that one can get from a Victorian government department. So this business of standing up here and blatantly telling what is not true-that is, that the party on our side of the House has not been providing land for Aboriginals-is wrong. Mr Tickner-In this place.

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Are you saying that it was never provided in the territory under a Liberal government? If you are, you had better check that as well. Mr Tickner-This is a debate about national government policy.

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Okay. Are we now just correcting it a bit? That is fair enough. Let me just point out to the minister that the amount of land provided by governments of both political persuasions in Western Australia-which is one of the states much accused by the minister-would look like the Pacific Ocean when compared with the amount provided in New South Wales. For the minister to get up here, bleed his heart all over the floor of this chamber and not tell the truth is starting to annoy some of us to the point where we will have to do something about it publicly. The minister generalises every time he gets on the radio and raises these sorts of issues. The shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs and I are simply asking the minister to look at the amendment. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has already said that he agrees with amendment No. 1. In fact, he gave a rather heated dissertation on the subject. Amendment No.2 simply expands amendment No. 1 and I cannot see how anybody could possibly disagree with amendment No.3. The fact of the matter is that this minister has been told by the Prime Minister (Mr KeatiTlg)-and the minister knows that this is true-who most certainly has never read and does not have the slightest intention of reading the amendments, to oppose all these amendments.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: It is important that we keep in mind the particular amendment with which we are dealing. The honourable member for Barker (Mr MCLachlan) and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) have made claims in connection with our response to this and other proposed amendments that simply cannot be substantiated. It is quite clear that there are two essential elements of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill, the first being the land acquisition function and the second being the land management function. Those opposite are attempting to claim that paragraph (t), which amendment No. 13 seeks to add to proposed subsection 191N(2), is designed in some way to complement or to improve the land management function. It does no such thing. The land management function within the context of this legislation is able to stand by itself. This part of the amendment suggests that, within the context of the national indigenous land strategy, there is: the need to give the upgrading of Aboriginal pastoral properties priority over the acquisition of land in areas where there are already substantial land holdings by Aboriginal people or corporations. That proposal does a number of things. The first thing it does is deliberately confuse the purpose of this legislation and particularly the provision in this legislation for land management considerations. The second thing it does is give credence to the claim made by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) earlier in the debate on another amendment when he said the real intent of the opposition is that the land should be used productively. That is an important provision. We would not retreat from that, but there are other considerations as well. In the context of proposed new paragraph (t), how would it be possible for the Indigenous Land Corporation to deal with a critical and important sacred site in an area where there are already substantialland holdings by Aboriginal people or corporations? How would it be possible for the Indigenous Land Corporation in a physical situation to give consideration to the purchase of land on which Aboriginals are actually living? I do not know where these proposals came from, but when we make the claimand this claim is echoed by people around Australia-that this is a deliberate ploy on the part of the opposition to delay, to frustrate, to circumvent and to damage this legislation we make it on good grounds. The honourable member for Barker made an interesting point in his most recent contribution to this debate on this amendment. When defending South Australia, he said that 20 per cent of the state had been made available to Aboriginal people. Let it be clearly seen on the record that this accords with the claim made by a member of the National Party some time ago that Aboriginal Australians, who represent something like three per cent of the Australian population, have ownership of about 17 per cent of Australia. It is said that a disproportionate area of Australia is under their ownership and control. We all know what that land is. If it was any good they would not have been allowed to keep it. The most productive areas, the coastal areas, the fishing areas and the areas where settlement was possible were acquired and alienated by European Australians. We left Aboriginal people in the desert. We left them 17 per cent of Australia. Everyone knows that South Australia is essentially a desert state. The 20 per cent of South Australia that the Aboriginal people have been allowed to have, acquire or keep is obviously the worse part of the desert. I bet they are not grazing many stock per hectare. That claim is a deliberate attempt to misrepresent the situation and make it appear that Aboriginal Australians in some way have been given a fair deal with land. They have not.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I will not waste any time answering the claims of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) because the things he is saying are becoming quite a joke and not worth replying to. I would like to put the record straight about one point because it concerns me that the wrong impression has been given. The member for Charlton said that I had offended some Aboriginal people in the gallery by my comments. Mr Robert Brown-You insulted them.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: That I 'insulted them', using the words of the member who insists on yelling across the House. I will give a direct quote from Hansard as to what actually took place. I said: I also realise that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) is playing incredible politics, especially to the gallery in which, I notice, there are members of the Aboriginal community. After the minister interjected by saying that he did not know they were there, I went on to say: Why would you be nodding to them if you did not . know they were there? How that could be taken as an insult to the members of the Aboriginal community, I do not know. But I want to clarify the record by giving the absolute assurance that there was never any insult intended to any member of the Aboriginal community, and the only insult perhaps that was intended concerned the behaviour of this minister, who has promoted division. I would now like to address my comments to the minister, who unfortunately is engaged in another conversation. I would like him to listen to what I have to say. Minister, you know very well that the divisiveness of this debate need not have gone on and that I came to you and said, 'Yes, we will give you in principle support for this fund, but I would like you to come back to us and have a look at our amendments.' This was an olive branch. You could have rung me up and said, 'Okay, Chris, let us sit down and discuss these amendments.' If you had been genuine, that is what you would have done. You may not have agreed with the amendments; we may not have been able to come to an agreement on some of them. But when that was all done it would have been seen by the population that, although the coalition and the government disagreed on some of the amendments, their goal was a united one and was for the benefit of the Aboriginal people. But this minister deliberately and utterly took the decision to play politics. Despite the fact that he goes around the country calling for bipartisanship, when bipartisanship is offered he turns his back and says, 'No, we will play politics.' He has played politics from the very beginning. I have referred before to the minister's efforts. He sent out letters to the churches saying to them, 'I urge you to urge the coalition to support the land fund.' Did he come to the shadow minister and say, 'Let's sit down and talk about how we can get together on this. '? No, he did not. He sent letters straight to the churches. At the weekend he sent out press releases saying, 'I urge the coalition to come out and support it fully,' which we had done, I might say, in the second reading debate. Did the minister send that press release to me? Did he phone me up? No, he sent that press release to the press and then he got the Aboriginal people to send the same one. Did it appear in the press? I got phone calls from members of the press, and they were laughing at these efforts of the minister who unfortunately has soiled his own reputation in this debate because he can no longer go around the country, as he has been doing, claiming bipartisanship. I have been very disappointed in the minister. I was disappointed in the minister when I attended a meeting of the Central Land Council where I heard him take credit for what bipartisanship had been achieved under the previous Prime Minister, Prime Minister Hawke. I heard the minister say, 'I did this. I achieved this. I got bipartisanship.' Did I once hear the minister refer to the coalition's previous shadow minister, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), and give him credit? Not one word was mentioned of the honourable member for Chisholm, who had worked so hard. There was not one mention of credit to the member for Chisholm, but when the government was asked why it had not done certain things, do you know what the reason was? It was, 'The coalition won't let us.' Every time this minister gets on his feet he cannot resist mentioning the coalition, and he mentioned it in such an inappropriate place as a meeting of the reconciliation council which was being videotaped and at which everyone was being non-political except the minister, who stood up and mentioned the coalition. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (1.09 p.m.)-I simply rise to tell the shadow minister, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), that she did not even know where she was. She was not at a meeting of the Central Land Council; she was at a meeting of the ATSIC regional councils in central Australia.

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I heard the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) dispute the claim that 20 per cent of South Australia is available to Aboriginal people. As that area is in my electorate, I want to make the point that it is not poor land; it is the land on which the Aboriginal people have lived for thousands of years; it is their land. Many Aboriginals criticise this legislation because, under the current land rights act which is administered by the state government, they no longer have access to that land in a way which is culturally appropriate to them and which would allow them to move into the 21st century with appropriate economic benefits. I stress to the minister and to the honourable member for Charlton that much of the Pitjantjatjara land is recognised as some of the best cattle country in Australia. It is certainly pastoral land; nevertheless, it is excellent cattle country. Part of it receives an average rainfall of 14 inches per annum, and in the previous 12 months it has received up to 22 inches of rain. So it is absolutely magnificent country. What is more important-and of cultural significance-is that it is the natural home of so many of our indigenous people. To say that we have not given them a fair deal or otherwise is inappropriate. In effect, we have quite rightly given them access to their own land; however, they do not have sufficient freedom to manage it in a way which many of them would like.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I wish to make some pertinent points about our proposed amendment to the bill. Firstly, the amendment that the coalition has put forward was exactly the reason that the land fund was mentioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Earlier in the debate I quoted from a letter that the Prime Minister wrote to Marshall Perron in the Northern Territory. He said that the land fund is for Aboriginal people who cannot benefit under the Native Title Act. This amendment will simply add to this bill that very important goal which all Aboriginal people thought would appear in the bill. It has been supported by Aboriginal people as recently as last night on the ABC. Mr Tickner-By one.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: By an ATSIC councillor and other Aboriginal people around the country who believed that this bill was for those people who cannot benefit from the Native Title Act. Last night on the radio I said that I have talked to Aboriginal people throughout Australia who have not had the benefit of reading this legislation. They understood that the land fund was for those Aboriginal people who had been dispossessed and who could not claim under the Native Title Act or under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That is the pertinent point of this amendment. The minister has not been able to argue against it because the Prime Minister's words stand in stark contrast to what the minister has been saying. That is the essence of this amendment which the minister will not even discuss.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I cannot allow the shadow minister to get away with this. Everyone knows that this effort on the part of the opposition is fraudulent. The purposes are not to improve the legislation; the purposes are to destroy the legislation. The shadow minister has indicated on the record that she did not discuss the opposition's proposed amendments with the Aboriginal community. As she just indicated, she gets her information about Aboriginal attitudes from the television. She then misrepresents the response of the Aboriginal people by referring to the comments of one ATSIC commissioner. She claims that what that one ATSIC commissioner has said represents the interests and the attitudes of Aboriginals right across Australia. It does not. The attempt by the shadow minister to misrepresent these circumstances brings to her no credit.

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I do not want to break the record of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who has now spoken 15 times on the bill. He has just misrepresented the shadow minister's position who, in the time that she has had this position, has been assiduous in getting around the Aboriginal industry and making sure that she listens to its views. To make sure the minister understands that not everybody in the Aboriginal industry is with him, I will quote from a paper that was put out in Western Australia called 'The Lawman's Vision'. There were quite a lot of rather revealing things said in that paper. One was about the gas pipeline company. Amongst other things, the paper said: An office has been established by the gas pipeline company to study sacred sites along the route. It then disagreed with the people who have made much of the sacred sites. It continues: All authority is hereby withdrawn from land councils and other self-appointed bodies. Let all Australians know that these organisations do not speak for the tribal lawmen or their people. That was signed by Arnold Franks and Billy Dunn on behalf of a number of Aboriginals who totally disagree with the minister. I can tell the minister that there are some more people in the Pitjantjatjara lands who disagree with the general thrust of what he has been doing. So please do not stand up here and try to represent the position that you are speaking for all Aboriginals because, increasingly, as your Native Title Act falls to pieces under the weightMr Tickner-You can't help yourself, can you!

text: Hindmarsh) (1.28 p.m.)by leave-I move: (14) Clause 3, page II, lines 11-13, omit proposed subsection 191 N(6), substitute the following subsection: Copy to be given to Minister " '(6) The Indigenous Land Corporation Board must give a copy of the national indigenous land strategy and a copy of any changes it has made to the national indigenous land strategy to the Minister within 2 months of the Board agreeing to the strategy or change.' ". (15) Clause 3, page II, after subsection 191N(6) add the following subsections: Copy to be tabled in each House " '(7) The Minister must cause a copy of the national indigenous land strategy or of any changes made to the national indigenous land strategy to be presented to each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the Minister has received the document. National indigenous land strategy etc to be disallowable by either House of Parliament " '(8) The national indigenous land strategy, and changes made to the national indigenous land strategy, are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interprefunds tation Act 190 l. Land not to be purchased, moneys not to be distributed etc until after national indigenous land strategy has been tabled etc. " '(9) The Indigenous Land Corporation must ensure that no land, or interest in land, chased and that no moneys are distributed for the performance of its functions under sections 191D and 191E before the time has expired during which either House may disallow, or be deemed to have disallowed, the national indigenous land strategy and, if the strategy has been disallowed or deemed to have been disallowed by either House, the Corporation must ensure that no land or interest in land is purchased unless and until a new strategy has been prepared and tabled.' ". Amendment No. 14 is a very minor amendment and deals with clause 3, page 11, lines 11-13 of proposed subsection 191N(6). Amendment No. 15 is much more substantial. I refer in particular to parts (7) and (8). The reason for these amendments is simply one of accountability of the ILC. Organisations that have a responsibility for spending public money-and especially organisations that are responsible for providing the best possible benefit to Aboriginal people-should be accountable. Unfortunately, recently we have had in the newspapers distressing accounts of money that has been meant for Aboriginal people going astray and not reaching the communities it has been meant for. Since I have taken on this portfolio, not a week has gone past when I have not received phone calls from members of Aboriginal communities saying, 'We have money that was directed to this community. Something has happened to it. Either it has been misappropriated or for some reason we have not got the money we expected to have because of some sort of failure of administration.Â· That is distressing to the Aboriginal community but, worse than that, by the time this is reported in the press it is often taken to reflect on the Aboriginal community. So Aboriginals are twice losers: they lose out when their community does not get the money that was earmarked for it; and they lose out when somehow they are deemed to be responsible for it. When Aboriginal people approach me they say, 'Look, we want to get out of this. These must be as accountable as any other fund.' They say, 'To have it any other way is total paternalism.' To think that Aboriginal funds have to be treated in different ways is paternalism. This is why we have moved that the ILC-which is responsible for the grantis puring of this money-put forth a strategy. The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 itself gives absolutely no goals to the ILC. It does not say what the goal of the ILC is or what direction it should take. The only thing the bill does in relation to giving direction to the spending of the funds and the investment of the funds while they are waiting to be spent is state that the ILC has to have a national land strategy. But there is no requirement that that nationalland strategy actually be formulated before the ILC goes out and spends funds. It is possible to have the ludicrous situation where the ILC, responsible to Aboriginal communities to spend money on behalf of Aboriginal communities in a logical and sensible wayin a way that assists Aboriginal communities-could go ahead and start the purchase of property or some other strategies before it had drawn up that national strategy. These are important amendments and we wish to add them to the bill.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: PAIRS
text: I absolutely and totally the line taken by the minister. If he would like to take a look what I said, I said that Aboriginal people have come to me when funds meant for them to have been misappropriated to other areas, often by white bureaucrats-more usually by white bureaucrats. When these people come to me they also say, 'We have rung Robert Tickner's office. We have asked for help from the minister and it has not been forthcoming.' In the points I have made there has been no slur on Aboriginal people. The slur is on this government because Aboriginal people have not got the funds that were meant for them. The minister asked me to list some other organisations that have disallowable instruments. I asked the Parliamentary Library for this information and it sent to my office five pages of disallowable instruments. Under the ATSIC Act of 1989 the disallowable instruments are, I believe, sections 4A, 40, 113, 116, 119, 127C, 130, 138 and 194. Disallowable instruments are not unusual. I reiterate that I resent absolutely the minister's efforts to play politics. Read my words in Hansard and see whether you can find anything that I have said that constitutes a slur on Aboriginal people. The truth is that in this House the only person who has tried to create division and indicate that there is any criticism of Aboriginal people is you and you stand condemned for it.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: PAIRS
text: Northern TerritoryParliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training) (1.39 p.m.)-I too heard what was said by the shadow minister. I have to concur with what was said by the minister in his contribution. The second of these two amendments reveals the agenda of the opposition. Using its numbers in the Senate, it wants to be able to frustrate the ambitions of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. That is very clear. I saw an interesting article in one of the newspapers today. It quoted an unnamed frontbencher from the opposition. That frontbencher was lamenting the fact that the opposition was not going to support the land title fund. The article in the Telegraph Mirror by Kim Sweetman states: A key frontbencher yesterday revealed sections the party wanted to support the Government's Aboriginal land acquisition fund legislation. I do not doubt that that is true. Those people in the party recognise, no doubt, the validity of the government's attempts to pass this legislation through this House. They have seen through the tawdry attempts, as the minister has said, of the opposition to frustrate attempts by Aboriginal people to manage their own affairs as they would want them to be managed and as we want them to manage them. The opposition is saying to Aboriginal people, 'You cannot make assessments or judgments. You have to table them in the House and they will be made a disallowable instrument.' That is what the amendment says. The opposition says to them, 'If we do not like the fact that you are going to purchase particular sets of properties around Australia we will disallow it.' Why would the opposition disallow it? It may not like the fact that they happen to be buying into country which it might want other people to purchase. Could it be that? Let us ask ourselves what the motives behind the opposition's approach to this particular issue are. I am not normally a cynical person, but one would have to approach the propositions of the opposition with a degree of cynicism. There is nothing surer than that the government will oppose this amendment, yet the opposition's support for the government's legislation rests on our accommodating its amendments. If the opposition were at all genuine in approaching the issue of the support of the land fund in a bipartisan manner it would see the amendment for what it really is: an attempt to obstruct and subvert the interests of Aboriginal people as represented by the ILC. The shadow minister's saying that Aboriginal people have been ringing her on a regular basis saying that funds have been diverted now takes a slightly different tack. Funds are not being diverted by Aboriginal people; they are being diverted by white bureaucrats. That is not a bad tum, but I suspect that nothing can be proven. They are allegations of misappropriation about which the shadow of minister has no proof, and allegations which she should not raise unless she has some proof. She should not malign people who are working for and on behalf of Aboriginal people through ATSIC. I assume that is the organisation she is talking about because it has the bulk of funds appropriated to Aboriginal people in this country through the federal government's programs. Or is she talking about misappropriation through state government agencies? In that case, she should say so. Let us ask which state governments she is talking about. If we are talking about the use of government funds, if people in this House are saying, 'Let us have a disallowable instrument on the way in which state governments use funds which are made available by the federal government,' then let it come from the opposition. As the minister rightly pointed out, the fact that this is a tawdry political stunt by the opposition. There is no way the government will support these amendments. The shadow minister knows that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) has recently said-I am not sure what they call him these days: Bozo?that if the government does not support these amendments the opposition will not support the legislation.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: PAIRS
text: Moreton) (1.44 p.m.)Despite the clarification provided by the shadow minister, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), that is not what her amendment says. Amendment No. 15 is very strongly and vigorously objected to by the government and will be opposed by the government for a very simple reason. The shadow minister might suggest that it is a very innocent proposal, a very innocent process, whereby the land strategy becomes a disallowable instrument, but the fact is that once it becomes a disallowable instrument in this House or in the Senate it can be obstructed or blocked for any reason. The worse part of it is that part of the amendment which proposes a new subsection (8) to make it a disallowable instrument, followed by proposed new subsection (9), which says that no moneys can be expended at all, no purchases of land can be made at all, until a new strategy that is approved by is the House of Representatives and the Senate is put in place. Therefore, it can very easily become a manipulated process whereby the Senate continues to block and block and block, and continues to say, 'This strategy is not acceptable for reason X, reason Y or reason Z.' Meanwhile, no funds are expended and no land is being purchased. I am particularly concerned that the shadow minister once more has raised allegations of misappropriation of funds. Once more, we have the process happening in this parliament where Aboriginal organisations or organisations which are supplying services to Aboriginal communities or groups are accused of misappropriation of funds. This allegation is made continually, particularly in the Senate but also in this House. It was the manner in which Aboriginal debates occurred in this House for eight to 10 years. On every single occasion that those allegations were made and there was a subsequent inquiry by the Auditor-General, by standing committees or by a whole range of other organisations there has never been any shred of evidence to prove the allegations. It is very easy to come into this place and accuse people of misappropriating funds. But those opposite are very silent when the Auditor-General tables a report in this place which says there is no evidence of misappropriation of funds. That is what occurred just recently. The Auditor-General conducted an inquiry into the Northern Land Council. That organisation had been subjected to vicious attack in the Senate, with allegations made about misappropriation and misuse of funds. But when the Auditor-General's office conducted a major inquiry into the Northern Land Council it found no evidence at all of misappropriation of funds. Did any opposition senator who had made those allegations get up in the Senate and say, 'I'm sorry, I was wrong, I apologise for misleading the Senate; I apologise for besmirching the reputations of those people'? No, and it will not happen on this occasion either. It is very easy to bandy about allegations misappropriation of funds but it is not so easy to prove them because in the vast majority of cases they do not exist; there has been no misappropriation of funds. What has often occurred is that particular groups have been unhappy that their proposal has not been funded but another organisation's proposal has been funded. So they ring up opposition members and say, 'Look, organisation X has got this money; we should have got this money. There is some funny business going on. The ATSIC regional councils are rigging this to suit themselves,' and opposition members are falling for that line. They see this some great evidence of misappropriation of funds. As honourable members know, there is never enough money in the pool to satisfy all the communities' needs. That is one of the points that all the regional councils will tell us-that they have 100 submissions for funding and they only have money to fund 15 or 20. Of course, that is always going to be the case. There will always be a greater level of demand than there is funding to support those submissions. But for the shadow minister to accuse the regional councils, the white bureaucrats who run ATSIC or whoever it is that she might be accusing of misappropriating funds because they make deliberate, strategic decisions to fund one organisation over another is a misuse of her role as shadow minister and an abuse of her position as a member of parliament. I believe the shadow minister should not make such allegations in the context of this debate unless she has some evidence to substantiate them. The fact that she receives a few phone calls from a few disgruntled people who were not able to be funded is not evidence of misappropriation and it is no reason to put into this legislation the process of a disallowable instrument. (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: PAIRS
text: Hindmarsh) (1.49 p.m.}-I thank the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) for his very sincere contribution to this debate. It stands in stark contrast to the contribution made by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). I will take on board what the memof ber for Moreton says because I believe that he sincerely wants to see the controversies taken out of Aboriginal affairs so it can be shown that we are all working towards the same goal. As one aside, I would not want to feel that I had misled the parliament in any way on this matter when I said before that I had in my room what looked like five or six pages of disallowable instruments. In fact, all I have with me at the moment-and I am not sure that this is the total list because it starts with the Telecommunications Act-is three pages of all types of disallowable instruments that as come before the parliament, probably 99.9 per cent of which pass without comment. One that I have picked out, for no good reason, is the Fisheries Act management plans. They are a disallowable instrument, as are all the others on this paper. That is simply to correct something I had said before about the number of pages of disallowable instruments I had. The honourable member for Moreton has made a very valid point. I thought I had made it very clear-if I had not, I will reiterate itthat there is not an accusation against any particular group or anything else. But we do see, with horrible regularity, suggestions in the newspapers of misuse-mismanagement is probably a better word-of funds. In Victoria, Ian Viner has been appointed to investigate some such charges. I think this causes enormous distress to all of us. What we are asking for is that when this strategy is drawn up and given to parliament it be drawn up in such a way that management goes ahead. The management should be clear so that everybody can see, ahead of time, the structure that has been put there so that there is no danger of these accusations and problems occurring. People should know how the organisation is working. They should know that there is a strategy of how government, public and Aboriginal funds will be distributed to the community and they should be able to see how that strategy is working, and that the strategy appears to be like all other disallowable instruments before parliament. I know this House has a very low opinion of the Senate, but to suggest that the Senate would quite maliciously single out this particular strategy for special treatment is perhaps unfair to the other place. If those opposI ite are suggesting that the combination of the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Greens and the Australian Democrats will disallow this instrument, then perhaps there would be something wrong with the way the strategy had been set up. I would then suggest that perhaps it should go back to the Indigenous Land Corporation for a wider strategy to be submitted. But I do not think we can suggest that those in the other place, however misguided they may be, are being deliberately malicious. I think that probably goes beyond the pale.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PAIRS

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PAIRS
text: It is most certainly very marginal land. I said that if it was of any quality it would have been alienated by white Australians some time in the last 200 years. The second point that I want to emphasise is that we must be forgiven if we believe, as have asserted, that the opposition's approach is fraudulent and is designed to filibuster, delay, destroy or damage this legislation because this particular proposal the opposition has brought before the House simply does not make sense within the context of the legislation. The opposition wants to amend proposed subsection 191N(6), which states: The Indigenous Land Corporation Board must give a copy of the national indigenous land strategy to the Minister on request. The opposition wants to amend that by putting a time limit on it. But there is no time limit on the minister. The minister can request a copy of that land strategy at any time. I do not know whether opposition members have read the legislation. If they have, they certainly have not understood it. If they had read it, they would have understood it and, for that reason, I have had my very firm conviction confirmed that the opposition's approach is fraudulent-and everyone in Australia knows it is fraudulent. These alleged phone calls to the shadow minister are a joke. Why, in heaven's name, would any Aboriginal person in Australia phone the office of the shadow minister? I get tired of the stupidity of the opposition. The minister has already drawn the opposition's attention to 191R(l), which states: The Indigenous Land Corporation must make a copy of the national indigenous land strategy or a regional indigenous land strategy available to any personany personwho asks for a copy. Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: PAIRS
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (2.24 p.m.)-This is a consequential amendment on the first amendment the coalition moved. That amendment has been exhaustively debated. I do not intend in the course of my remarks to do any more than respond to the shadow minister. I think my colleagues also wish me to do that. When the coalition talked about the amendment that it sought government support for, it neglected to say what the nature of the amendment was that it was seeking to introduce into this bill. I place on the public record the fact that since the national parliament started to make laws with respect to Aboriginal affairs-it gained that power in 1967; it was not actively taken up until the time of the WhitIam government and it continued through the period of the Whitlam government, the Fraser government, the Hawke government and the Keating government through the whole operation of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission-the consistent cross-party position has been that grants of money would not be handed over to individual Aboriginal people to buy land. That has been a consistent hallmark of Commonwealth policy for in excess of 20 years. That has always been the policy. What did we find? At five minutes to midnight, when we were well into the debate on this legislation in the House of Representatives, the shadow minister pulled out an amendment from her back pocket which sought to overturn over 20 years of crossparty supported policy in Aboriginal affairs. Then she says to the government in mock horror and indignation, 'You reject our amendments. You do not want cross-party support.' She not only did not consult with the government before the amendments were brought in but also did not consult with one Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person in this country. In the course of the debate today on one of the amendments, a transcript of a radio interview yesterday was dragged up involving one Aboriginal person on one regional council. There are 35 ATSIC regional councils in this country. Is it any wonder that the government is not prepared to support this amendment? It is poor public policy. It is not just the government that is not prepared to accept the amendment. If those opposite talk to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people around the country they will find that they do not want this amendment either. They do not want the amendment because it not only lowers the public accountability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs to the Australian parliament and the people of Australia but also lowers the public accountability of Aboriginal policy to indigenous people themselves. This amendment is not supported by either indigenous people or the government. I challenge the shadow minister to go on talkback radio programs like the Sattler program in Western Australia and try to sell this policy publicly. She should go and tell people listening to those talkback programs how the coalition wants to make grants of money to individual Aboriginal people to allow this land fund to proceed in this way. It is not the government's policy. It is not the policy of Aboriginal people. It overturns 20 years of cross-party support for good public policy in this area. We absolutely reject this amendment.  about a minute and half to contribute to the debate on this amendment. I put on record the coalition's position in regard to these consequential amendments, which deal with sections 1915, 191T and 191U. The government has to understand what the coalition is seeking to do by these amendments. The coalition is seeking to expand the range of people who can be affected by this legislation. Far from trying to narrow the effect of the legislation to corporations, we seek to include individuals and trusts to broaden the effect that the land fund will have on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Speaker: Mr BEDDALL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I point out that some of the debate that has taken place between the states and the Commonwealth through the COAG process, particularly that which occurred at the meeting held at Hobart in February last year, has led to some significant changes in the Australian gas industry. For too long in this country gas was locked up in individual states and the movement of gas, particularly that of natural gas, between states was restricted. We have now seen the real benefits of the COAG process in the gas reforms that it is bringing forward. Last week I was able to sign a contract that allowed the construction of a new ethane pipeline from Moomba to the ICI Botany plant in Sydney. The pipeline which will be owned by ICI will cost some $300 million$200 million for the construction of the pipeline and $100 million for the infrastructure at the Botany plant. What is significant about this is that this the first time this type of process has been able to take place. To a large extent, there is private investment in the Australian gas industry. For Australia, this is just a good news, good news story. In the past, the ethane was reinjected into the ground because there was no efficient use for it in the Moomba field. This project will create 1,000 jobs at the height of the construction phase, a $35 million investment by the Cooper Basin producers at Moomba and a $50 to $100 million expansion of the petrochemical industry in New South Wales. More importantly for Australia, it will produce $100 million per annum of import replacement over a lO-year period, which amounts to in excess of $11 billion. The ethane pipeline is a landmark project and shows that cooperation between the Commonwealth and the states can lead to significant changes in our infrastructure program. Other major projects that are under way or are on the drawing board include the goldfields project in Western Australia. Again, it will be a private sector pipeline with the Western Mining Corporation, Normandy Poseidon and BHP Minerals involved. The other ones that are of significant benefit to Australia are the Bass Strait to Sydney pipeline and the Otway to Adelaide pipeline, which could be providing gas to those areas. Interest Rates

text: The figures show that our 28.5 per cent of GDP was 10 per cent below the OECD average, which was 38.8 per cent. We have been aware of the importance of ensuring that our tax regime, so far as is possible, does not provide a disincentive to investment in Australia. In that respect, we have been conscious of the business tax regimes operating in Asian countries and we have moved to provide some comparability with various recent moves related to accelerated depreciation and investment allowances and the cut in the company tax rate from 39c to 33c in the dollar. With that we have made Australia reasonably competitive. If we look at the corporate tax rates of Australia and of east Asian countries, we see that Australia has a rate of 33 per cent which compares with Japan at 37 1h per cent-it is higher than us-Indonesia at 35 per cent; and the Republic of Korea at 34.4 per cent. Below us is Malaysia at 32 per cent-only fractionally below us; Thailand at 30 per cent; Singapore at 27 per cent; Taiwan at 25 per cent; and Hong Kong at 16 1h per cent. So we are obviously, apart from those at the lower end of that spectrum, very much in a position of comparability with the Asian countries in our business tax regime. I was also asked by the honourable member about the implications of all of that for public services. text: Can the Minister for Communications and the Arts inform the House of the findings of the recent inquiry held into the financial management of the ABC's Asian satellite television service Australia Television? I commissioned a review of the service, which focused on financial and management aspects, and the review was conducted by senior officers from my department and the Department of Finance with the cooperation of senior officers from the ABC. After I received the review's report last week, I forwarded it to the ABC board for its comment, and last night I received the board's response. The key findings of the review are that, while the service costs twice as much as originally estimated, it has been successfully established and it is making a contribution to Australia's objectives in the South-East Asian region. However, these findings are dependent on the service's ability to repay to the ABC an internal line of credit with interest, and that has been extended to Australia Television over the last two years. The review has also raised some issues of financial accountability, which is of relevance to all of the ABC's commercial enterprises. I am pleased to table the review, a letter of my own to the Chairman of the ABC, Professor Armstrong, and two letters in reply from Professor Armstrong. Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister advise the House of the progress being made in implementing world's best practice into the Child Support Agency?

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I can inform the House that I will be introducing legislation next month to make the child support scheme more flexible. The legislation will allow all regular payers to pay privately. That will speed the system up. It will allow stage one parents who become unemployed to skip the court process and change their payments by simple agency notification. It will also allow for simpler proof of parentage requirements. The big improvement for the Child Support Agency will be in the area of phone contact. Most child support offices have already installed new telephone technology, which has dramatically reduced delays. I can inform the House that all offices will be equipped with this new technology by the end of January. By that time we will have a voice messaging system up and running. This will allow parents to ring up 24 hours a day and get details of payments and arrears. The exciting news is that we are working on a vastly superior phone service-an autobank service for child support clients which will be known as the Child Support Infobank. This package is already in use in Massachusetts, and 60 per cent of calls there are answered electronically. In addition to the benefits of the voice messaging system where details of payments can be obtained, the infobank will also give information on things like arrears, the review processes, how to contact the local representative on the registrars advisory panel, the law and the operation of the child support act. People can receive a hard copy of that information by pressing the may star button. If they want to go through to an operator they can just press the hash button. I am told that this service has been enormously popular in Massachusetts. Like electronic banking, people have learnt to use it fairly quickly. Evidence shows that the clients in Massachusetts are attracted by the privacy that the child support infobank offers. It has greatly improved its client service and it has freed up staff for the difficult cases. Best of all, it is not all that expensive. In relation to world's best practice, I can tell the honourable member that in many areas we are the model for the world's best practice. With collection rates at around 70 per cent we are amongst the best in the world. By comparison the United States, which has had a service operating for about 20 years, has a collection rate of about 19 per cent. Over the next few years, we will also be employing another 150 staff to assist with the collection of arrears because we know that we can do much better. We are also amongst the world leaders in public education. Title: PRIVILEGE
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a matter of privilege. I wish to raise an issue of potential applicability to us all. When the proposed new electoral boundaries for Victoria were released by the Australian Electoral Commission in August, members of parliament and electors generally were given an opportunity to object and to submit amendments to the redistribution, as provided in the act. One honourable member from this side of House made such an objection, and proposed new boundaries. As I understand it, he was told that his objections could only be considered today, 20 September, a parliamentary sitting day. If this is correct, then the honourable member was given Buckley's choice: he could attend the AEC hearing or he could attend the parliament and lose the chance to put his case. The process adopted by the AEC appears to be one of blatant disregard to the primary obligation of members to attend the parliament when it is sitting. I submit that, if the AEC has insisted that the honourable member should attend during this sitting week instead of hearing his objections last week, next week or Friday of this week, which is not a sitting day, it has forced to him to absent himself from a parliamentary sitting and, therefore, he is in breach of the privileges of the House. Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to section 49 of the constitution. I also draw your attention to section 14 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, which states: (a) a member shall not be required to attend before a court or a tribunal ... on any which the House of which that Member is a member meets. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) is in a comparable situation. He was also told that he could discuss matters that concerned him, but only today and only by a telephone call which would be made at a time that suited the commission and not him. It seems to me that there has been a prima facie breach of privilege. On behalf of the House, I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to draw to the AEC's attention its obligation to observe the rules of the House and to recognise the primary obligation of members to attend. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to write to the AEC, drawing its attention to section 14 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 and inviting it to observe the act when calling members before it.

This is not simply a welfare matter. It is a question of the national economic interest. Having made the problem so much worse by its appalling economic management, the government must now act to keep as much of this nation's farm assets intact as possible against that day when rain does come, against that day when we then expect the rural sector to get back on its feet quickly and start producing national export dollars again. The costs of not doing so will be immense. Report after report from Queensland in of particular, but now increasingly from the rest of the nation, highlights the sell-off of breeding stock in this country-particularly cows in calf in Queensland-and the loss of export income both now and after the drought from the biggest rural export industry is potentially enormous. If we do not take some steps now to prevent it happening, those costs will go on for years after the drought ends. Wool International-it is interesting that seems to be more observant about what is happening in this context than the Australian government-reckons that international wool buyers are worried that wool growers will not be able to restock if they lose their flocks now. They are watching the scene and saying, 'There is plenty of wool now in the stockpile, but if growers lose their flocks they are not going to be able to rebuild them because they are so financially weakened.' Wool International sees the problem, yet this mob opposite apparently cannot. The government does not seem able to perceive that, without adequate measures now not only to meet the welfare needs-if you like, the relief side of the equation-but also to ensure retention of our farmers and their asset base and recovery when rains come, very expensive things will happen. Let me put it to the House that, if we lose another 4,000 farmers as a result of this drought and the government's inactivity, and they all claim their re-establishment grants, the government will have to payout well over $200 million directly in re-establishment grants and it will then have to support them on welfare. I remind you that the biggest sector of the manufacturing industry in this country is the food processing sector. The opposition also tries to argue that we delayed a response to the drought. I take this opportunity to debunk this myth. Since September 1992 the Commonwealth has allocated $47.2 million in direct drought assistance through the rural adjustment scheme. The government has also agreed to match, on a dollar for dollar basis, the 'Farmhand' public drought appeal brought forward by Channel 9. At present, the 'Farmhand' appeal, through the Nine Network, has raised $4 112 million and the estimates are that, with the Commonwealth matching commitment, the total could amount to $10 million. The states have also provided significant drought support. Since 1991 the Queensland and New South Wales governments have provided over $60 million for drought relief. Last August the Commonwealth provided an extra $14 million package. It included an extra $2112 million in exceptional circumstances support under RAS to Queensland. This was in addition to the $4.5 million for drought assistance under RAS for Queensland in the last budget. The package also contained an extra $5 million exceptional circumstances support to New South Wales as well as the extension of the Task project in Queensland and into New South Wales. There was also some $1.39 million to increase financial and family counselling and communicate financial assistance measures available for drought. We have also announced relaxation of guidelines for eligibility under the assistance for isolated children's scheme. Our policy approach encourages primary producers to adopt self reliant approaches in managing risk. That is what has been done to date and cabinet, of course, will go much further tomorrow. We have never sat back and said that it was a one-off effort. We always review our policies to make sure that they keep on hitting the mark. A special task force has been established in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and a Commonwealth interdepartmental committee has been convened to consider the adequacy of Commonwealth programs. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and the department have consulted widely with key groups, including the National Farmers Federation, rural counsellors, private charity groups and the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council. Continuing talks have also taken place with affected states. A special meeting of the Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand has been called for Friday to discuss the drought issues-in other words, all state and Commonwealth ministers will meet this Friday. Senator Collins has also undertaken to review the RAS exceptional circumstances guidelines, and the advisory council has been asked to provide the minister with advice on possible changes to RAS to address perceived problems. In the past-in the opposition's time-drought assistance measures provided by the state and territory governments varied significantly but generally took the form of concessional loans for carry-on purposes or for very specific purposes, such as financial aid for eligible activities. Since the signing of the national drought policy statement in 1992, the states and territories have moved towards implementing its range of measures-measures based on the principles of sustainable development, risk management, productivity growth and structural adjustment in the farm sector. This has generally involved the phasing out of transaction based subsidies that may have been provided during periods of drought. Unfortunately, these things are way beyond the comprehension of the National Party, which is only on about rhetoric and trying to look good and present an image of caring. But all of us know of its faults because its own spokespeople are saying these things to the government. The government has never run away from recognising the seriousness of the position facing our farm sector. In New South Wales, average farm cash income for broadacre farms is expected to fall, unfortunately, by around 50 per cent in 1994-95 to $19,500 per farm. It is a great tragedy that some 26 per cent of farms are expected to have negative farm cash income in the financial year 1994-95. The largest relative falls in income are expected in the wheat and other crops industry, where average farm cash income is expected to fall from $161,700 in 1993-94 to around minus $8,300 in 1994-95. Many of these farms had well above average crops in 1993-94, which highlights the variability the rural sector faces. Farm cash incomes in the livestock industries in New South Wales are expected to remain relatively unchanged in 1994-95. In the sheep industry, higher prices for wool are likely to offset slightly lower production and increased fodder costs, but the level of income is forecast to continue to remain at depressed levels. In the beef industry, forced slaughterings are expected to maintain incomes in the short run. However, the cost of restocking properties is likely to reduce incomes in later years. Average farm cash income for broadacre farms in Queensland in 1994-95 is expected to fall by around 15 per cent to $33,200. Unfortunately, some 38 per cent of farms in Queensland are expected to suffer negative farm cash income in 1994-95. text: page) (4.16 p.m.)From the very outset let me say that the federal Labor Party is vitally concerned with the rural sector and the difficulties that it is presently facing. Over recent years, the rural sector has experienced a great deal of hardship. Successive years of weak commodity prices, world recession and declining terms of trade have resulted in low incomes for many. Farmers have responded to these financial pressures by increasing on-farm productivity and/or reducing expenditure. It presently has, and will in the future have, policies regarding drought, including the package that will be presented tomorrow. For the opposition, particularly the National Party, which at the present time is absolutely discredited in a policy sense, to come in here and carry on in its hypocritical way-the same way that it has done for years-shows an enormous amount of gall and hide. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) has recently been criticised for going to various meetings-Liberal Party meetings in Western Australia, League of Rights meetings and other meetings-and simply telling people what they wanted to hear.
