For the benefit of the rest of the honourable members, I will tell them a bit about that paper. The honourable member talks about winning the vote of influential community leaders. This concerns rural and regional development because he is the shadow spokesman. He talks about infrastructure. He says, 'We need to set a figure-$1 billion, $3 billion.' I have moved these amendments together because we will not call divisions on them. Amendment No. 23 seeks to add after proposed subsection 191U(2) that 'section 47 of the Native Title Act 1993 does not apply to land acquired by a body corporate, person or trust under subsection (1)'. We believe it is extremely important that Aboriginal people who acquire land have the same flexibility as others with respect to what they do with their land. The amendment will not affect Aboriginal occupation and use of the land. The community can make the choice as to what it wants to do with the land. However, it allows greater flexibility for the community to sell or mortgage the land or use it as security. In other words, it can operate the land commercially through normal commercial practices. Amendment No. 24 seeks to omit paragraph (a) and substitute: 'a Chairperson appointed by the Prime Minister'. This is in relation to the board of the ILC. text: Northern TerritoryParliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training) (4.35 p.m.)-I want to address amendment No. 23, which seeks to override a key element of the agreement reached between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), on behalf of the government, and Aboriginal people in the native title negotiations so that the Native Title Act would not apply. It seems to me that amendment No. 23 exhibits very clearly for all the world to see the true intention of the opposition's position. It is effectively saying for that Aboriginal people who may purchase land under the land fund biII should, as a result of those purchases, disallow themselves from making application under the Native Title Act in relation to that land. I must say that I find that very difficult to understand. I cannot quite understand why the opposition is so opposed to it, unless this is another way of indicating its opposition to the Native Title Act. If that is the case-I assume that it is-it clearly demonstrates that the opposition has learnt absolutely nothing about the concerns and aspirations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. In the course of this debate, the opposition has posited 37 amendments. Its support or otherwise for this bill is contingent upon the government accepting those amendments. Time and again, government members have got up and said to us, 'This is what the Aboriginal people want and that is what the Aboriginal people want.' I can tell you that in this drought, which may be one of the greatest of all time, farmers want a lot of things too, but we know that good sense means they cannot have all of those things that they might want on any particular occasion. The government's duty is obviously to come up with a responsible bill which not only deals with the aspirations of Aborigines but also reassures a whole lot of other Australians that their rights are not going to be infringed either. The purpose of amendment No. 23 is to separate native title from the land acquisition fund. I will just take honourable members back to what was said in the preamble of the Native Title Act and in the explanatory memorandum: the land acquisition fund was for those Aborigines who had been dispossessed of native title. For reasons I explained earlier, it is now gone. Now we are going to acquire pastoral leases with the land acquisition fund. The government member who just spoke, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), said that Aboriginal people should not be prevented from attempting to establish that native title existed in those areas. But the whole purpose of this fund is to go into areas where native title was not able to be established. As the honourable member for CharIton (Mr Robert Brown) said a fortnight ago and again here this morning, that was the purpose of this bill. That is why we tried to get that previous amendment brought into this land acquisition fund biII-which you would not have. It was a perfectly innocuous amendment. It was actually almost word for word along the lines of your intention in the Native Title Bill. So here we are trying to separate the two so that you do not have a situation where tenure or title that exists at the present time is confused with native title. Let me give you one very good reason for that. Perhaps the minister sitting at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), can explain something when he gets up. Let us say that we get foot-andmouth disease in this country. Can the minister tell me whether or not those areas subject to native title-with, in some cases, stringencies of access for other people-will be subject to the sorts of ingredients, terms, conditions, and instant and urgent actions that will be required to stop the progress of a disease like foot-and-mouth disease? I will the minister something. If he can answer that, I will be very surprised because the bureaucrats responsible for dealing with that matter in South Australia do not know the answer. I hope he can answer that in a positive sense. There are all sorts of problems and reservations that local councils have to deal with. They have the right to go onto people's properties and so do other institutions. As we have tried to do in several parts of the biII, we are trying to make sure that those original titles stay as they are: acquired by Aborigines under the ILC but with the title staying the same. I know that the minister does not know the answer. He has to ask his advisers but he might take some time to find out the answers to those questions because it is a very important matter for the future administration of country-by states, by local councils and by all sorts of authorities who have responsibility for those areas.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: The honourable member for Barker (Mr MCLachlan) is now introducing another element into this debate by talking about footand-mouth disease. It is a genuine concern and a genuine issue and I appreciate the fact that it is an issue that needs resolution, but let us not hide what is the real motivation behind this amendment. It has nothing to do with foot-and-mouth disease. It has nothing to do with any of the extraneous matters that the member for Barker might wish to bring into the debate. This is all about a re-run of the native title debate which the opposition so culpably failed to participate in last time by just ruling itself out of the debate by saying that it opposed the whole bill. It excluded itself from the process. It marginalised itself from the debate about native title. It exposed the shallowness of its policy position on native title in November last year and it is trying now to have another bite at the cherry by re-entering this whole debate about native title legislation. By this amendment the opposition is attempting to defeat one of the principal clauses in the Native Title Act to make sure it cannot apply. The honourable member for Barker in his tell contribution said that opposition members have tried to show some responsibility in designing amendments that they felt would make the legislation stronger and better, but the big problem opposition members have is that they have designed these amendments in total isolation. It is not a question of the government saying that we want to give everything to the Aboriginal community. Of course we know that that is not possible. Government will always have many more demands placed upon it than it can ever actually meet. The government has not tried to give everything that the Aboriginal community could possibly ever want through this legislation, but we have tried to negotiate with Aboriginal people about how they believe this this fund should operate and what types of operations should occur. There have been meaningful, mature negotiations between two sides to come up with a package of proposals that not only reflects the government's needs and responsibilities and the processes of accountability that are required in such legislation but also meets the aspirations and needs of Aboriginal people. That contrasts completely with the opposition's proposals and its modus operandi. It sits in its own quiet, little room and thinks up ways to sabotage this bill. That is what this amendment is all about. This is just one more plank in the opposition's attempt to sabotage the land acquisition fund and at the same time try to sabotage the native title legislation. It has nothing to do with higher, principled issues such as foot-and-mouth disease, which the honourable member for Barker knows that members on this side of the House would of course be very concerned about. Of course we would be making sure that every effort is made to ensure that we have procedures to handle that on native title land or on pastoral land or any other form of land. We have as much a sense of responsibility for the country and for pastoral activity as the opposition does. Let us not try to hide the real motivation behind those fine objectives. We know that the opposition is seeking in this legislation to discriminate against indigenous people who obtain land through the land fund and prevent them from exercising their rights under the native title legislation. The opposition has no right to do that. It is certainly not something it has arrived at because it has tried to consult with Aboriginal people and has found that this is something they want. This is something the opposition has dreamed up in its little committee room with no consultation whatsoever, with no consideration of the true aspirations of Aboriginal people. The government will not wear that. The Aboriginal communities around this country will not wear it and it is about time the opposition understood that, to arrive at good public policy, to handle Aboriginal and islander aspirations and needs, it cannot just think it up in its committee room the day before legislation is about to be presented in the House and then suggest that it has done the good deed of coming up with amendments. It actually has to go out and talk to people. It actually has to find out what they really want. I assure the opposition that Aboriginal people support the land acquisition fund as the government has structured it because the government consulted widely in structuring this legislation. It talked with Aboriginal organisations and individual Aboriginal people throughout the length and breadth of this country. They want the clauses as the government has provided, not the opposition's shoddy little amendments which are an attempt to in fact rewrite the native title legislation and deny Aboriginal people their legitimate aspirations.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: I would just like to point out to the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) that one of the problems we are facing at the moment is the banks. Aboriginal people acquiring land have aspirations. Unfortunately, at the moment, where native title is involved the banks are refusing to lend money. So, when land is bought for Aboriginal people so they can develop that land-and I am not saying it has to be bought for that purpose, but when it is-and the land is subject to native title, the banks will not lend money. Those Aboriginal people are prevented from going through the normal means of commerce to obtain loans and mortgages from the banks to use that land in a profitable, economic way, to develop it and do all the other things that people want to do when they hold land for commercial reasons. So for the member for Moreton to suggest that there is something shoddy and underhanded about this does him no credit. I am surprised and disappointed that he has entered the debate in this way. I think you will find that it is in the interests of everybody that Aboriginal people have land that can be used to the fullest.

text: I think it is important for us to put this amendment, together with a number of the other amendments, in context. I refer to a cutting from the Australian dated 26 August 1994-not so long ago. The member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), who I think is the member for the second biggest electorate in this country, has itemised a number of times in this House how people of the Pitjantjatjara lands disagree with the fact that they do not have the ability to financially use that enormous and wonderful asset which is the Pitjantjatjara lands, to which they have inalienable freehold title. I thought I would raise those matters because government members like to give the impression that they are the only people who speak for Aborigines. Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (5.00 p.m.)-A number of amendments are being debated at once at this point of time in the debate. No doubt one of the most significant amendments moved by the coalition is amendment No. 23-despite the fact that all the amendments moved by the coalition make very slight changes, as described by the shadow minister in the last week. The member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is quite right in saying that the time to be counted is fast approaching. I would hope that before the hour is out we can see where the coalition stands with respect to the land fund bill. Amendment 23 seeks to override a key element of the agreement reached between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), on behalf of the government, in his and the government's negotiations with indigenous representatives over the Native Title Act. I remind the House that section 47 of the Native Title Act is designed to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who are also owners of a pastoral lease over the same land to claim native title, notwithstanding that the grant of the pastoral lease would ordinarily have extinguished native title. Section 47(3) of the act importantly goes on to make it clear that the effect of a native title determination is essentially-and I emphasise this point-that the pastoral lease will continue to apply to the land, including any covenants in the lease regarding the use of the land. This means, in very clear and precise terms, that the land will remain subject to the pastoral lease. That, in part, answers the issue earlier raised by the honourable member for Barker (Mr MCLachlan). But I do particularly refer him and the South Australian government to section 8 of the Native Title Act, which says: This Act is not intended to affect the operation of any law of a State or a Territory that is capable of operating concurrently with this Act. Quite clearly, on its face, the intention of the parliament is that the ordinary laws of the land will continue to apply. I do suggest that the South Australian government needs to get better legal advice if it is in some doubt about foot-and-mouth programs. Mr MCLachlan-it has nothing to do with legal advice; it is how the bureaucrats have been operating.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: LAND CORPORATION AND LAND
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (5.05 p.m.)-Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I want to return to amendment No. 23 and make some concluding remarks in respect of that amendment. I want to emphasise to the House that what we are seeing here is undoubtedly the first salvo of the attempt by the coalition to attack the Native Title Act in practice and in this parliament. It is the first step of the on the record commitment of the federal coalition to attack what is the most important human rights legislation enacted by this parliament pursuant to the 1967 referendum. The clause it seeks to attack is not some peripheral clause. It is an essential element of the agreement, the negotiated outcome, that occurred not only with indigenous people but also with other major industry participants in this country, in particular the National Farmers Federation. While the coalition was marginalised, out on the fringe, isolated and alone, it was the government which was dealing with the main players, talking to the pastoral industry and getting this very significant negotiated outcome. I urge the coalition to have a look around the world and just see what comparable conservative parties are doing in their negotiations with indigenous people. I tell members of the opposition without hesitation that they are out of step with their comparable conservative parties around the world. In Canada the former conservative government of Mr Mulroney was taking the leadership to negotiate with peak representatives of indigenous people on the issues of constitutional reform. Their representatives were sitting at the negotiating table with provincial governments. In the United States of America, going back not only to the time of Ronald Reagan but indeed to the period of Richard Nixon, it has been people on the conservative side of United States politics who have been recognising the rights of self-determination of indigenous people. It is not some pinko plot. This is mainstream conservative politics in the United States of America. In New Zealand the government of Mr Bolger, a conservative government, is seeking to negotiate a settlement of the Treaty of Waitangi in 1840. In the United States of America President Clinton earlier this year, on 29 April, issued a major executive order reaffirming his commitment to some of those principles that his opponents on the other side of politics had supported but indeed taking it further into a modem day dimension of respecting the rights of indigenous people. So it is in this country that when the history books are written not only will they and future generations applaud the Native Title Act but they will also applaud the processes that reached that just outcome. I believe those negotiations and that process that led to the final legislation is in many respects as important as the final outcome. After all that, and despite what is happening in the rest of the world, what is the coalition's position? The coalition's position is, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) has put on the public record before, a commitment to repeal the act. If he moves away from that to become moderate, he leaves a hanging threat to repeal the Native Title Act because not once has he ruled out the threat to repeal that legislation. When the coalition's Aboriginal affairs policy is up for review the most important element of that policy, the Native Title Act, will be excluded from the review. When the shadow minister comes in here and purports to express coalition policy with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Isiander affairs, the rest of us in this parliament and in the wider Australian community can be forgiven for thinking that the people who really call the shots in the coalition are the leader himself, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the member for Barker (Mr MCLachlan), the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and those whom I would describe as the hard men of the Liberal Party front-bench. In describing the hard men of the coalition cabinet I exclude the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), who by her own actions has somewhat marginalised herself in wielding influence in the coalition. The bottom line is that we are seeing a hardline anti-Aboriginal policy being manifested in amendment 23. It seeks to gut a key element of the Native Title Act. The government will not accept the amendment. (Time expired) Amendments negatived.

Title: PAIRS
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (5.49 p.m.)-in reply-In view of the fact that the shadow minister has made some remarks that deserve a response, I propose to speak very briefly at this time. I think it is important to place on the public record the government's commitment throughout the whole of this process to try to achieve the unanimous support of the Australian parliament for the establishment of the land fund. That public commitment on the part of the government goes right back to the time when the member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) was the Leader of the Opposition. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) wrote to the him many months ago seeking the coalition's views on the land fund. There was no response to that letter. The Prime Minister then introduced the legislation into the parliament over two months ago and sought coalition support for that legislation. Further to that, he wrote to the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) seeking his constructive comments to the legislation. No response was received to that letter from the Prime Minister. I think it is again important to place on the public record that the government's legislation comes to this House only after the most exhaustive process of public consultation, involving in the end key representatives of indigenous people and a negotiated outcome that I think makes very important gains for indigenous people while balancing the advance in human rights with very significant principles of public accountability. After all that, the government then moved to debate the legislation in the House of Representatives. The debate began but there were no coalition amendments. The debate proceeded and still there were no coalition amendments. Throughout the course of that day I was given a number of documents, some of them stamped 'confidential', being drafts of the coalition amendments. Those were the documents that I worked on and which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission advised me on and, ultimately, I advised the Prime Minister what the government's response to the legislation should be. I took the view that, ultimately, what was important was to get legislation through the parliament. It was very important, if we could, to get unanimous parliamentary support. But what I was not prepared to support and what the Prime Minister and the government was not prepared to support were amendments that were going to cause great concern to Aboriginal people and that were going to be strongly opposed by them. It came to my attention that before the coalition introduced the amendments into the parliament not one single Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person in this entire country was consulted about the content of those amendments. Mr Thckey-That is not so. I certainly did. Mrs Gallus-That is not true, and you know it.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: PAIRS

I want to pay tribute to all my colleagues on this side of the House who have participated in this debate. We stand to be counted, as the deputy chairperson of ATSIC asked us to be, in support of what is one of the most important pieces of social justice legislation ever to pass through this parliament. Speaker: Mr ALDRED
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to speak on an extraordinary scandal involving the Goss Labor government in Queensland and its administration, including the CJC. It came to national prominence in the Senate on 31 August 1994 following the tabling of the unanimous all-party report by the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing which called on the Goss government to establish an independent review into unresolved whistleblower cases. The case I am referring to is known as the Kevin Lindeberg case. It centres around the shredding of public records commonly known as the Heiner inquiry documents and tapes by order of the Goss cabinet on 5 March 1990 in order to reduce the risk of legal action. The Brisbane Courier-Mail on 3 September this year called it the great shredding affair. I took the trouble to obtain Mr Lindeberg's submissions to the Senate whistleblowing committee and also followed very closely the events on the floor of the Queensland's parliament some weeks ago when this affair flared up. The facts show that the cabinet deliberately misled the state archivist by letter dated 23 February 1990 in order to obtain her approval to destroy evidence required for litigation and then it wilfully ordered the destruction on 5 March 1990 in order to escape court action. The facts show that the Crown had been served with due and proper notification of a commencement of court proceedings by a firm of solicitors on 15 February 1990. The facts show that Queensland minister Anne Warner even admitted publicly on 8 September 1994 that she had possession of the solicitor's letter on 19 February 1990. She clearly knew what was going on. In other words, the Crown knew about the foreshadowed litigation involving the Crown itself and then secretly and wilfully set about attempting to obstruct justice by deliberately misleading the state archivist and others. I have in my possession the letter to the state archivist which clearly and falsely informs the archivist that the public reportand I stress 'public records'-'is no longer required or pertinent to the public records'. This was stated at the very time the government knew of the anticipated court proceedings. By law it is an offence to mislead a public official, which is what the Goss cabinet did. We even have a senior public servant with knowledge of the anticipated litigation secretly and actively destroying the evidence. That same public servant even helped prepare the cabinet's submissions on each occasion, and he would not act alone. Anyone who has the slightest knowledge of criminal law knows that the course of justice can be perverted without judicial proceedings being under way just so long as the conspirators have foreknowledge of it and seek by deception to obstruct it. Not only did the shredding obstruct justice, it utterly stopped it and was ordered by the Goss cabinet, the respondent in the proposed action. Mr Truss-Shame.

Speaker: Mr ALDRED
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It is, too. The facts show that the Goss government has actually confirmed possession of the solicitor's letter and stated publicly that it ordered the destruction 'in order to reduce the risk of legal action'. Moreover, what makes this story so remarkable is that the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission can allegedly find no official misconduct, which raises questions of the gravest nature over its so-called independence. I seek leave to table a letter of 23 February 1990 from the Goss cabinet to the Queensland state archivist. It has already been tabled in the Queensland parliament.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It is often said that to ensure thriving democracy we need a strong opposition. These are very difficult times for the opposition and they are very difficult times for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer). We have seen in today's Australian Newspoll that the fortunes of the Leader of the Opposition and the opposition have plummeted. We see the two-party preferred vote: ALP 50 per cent, Liberal-National parties 38 per cent. The satisfaction rating of the Leader of the Opposition: 23 per cent satisfied, 58 per cent dissatisfied. For preferred Prime Minister: Keating 52 per cent, Downer 25 per cent. But you really must admire the persistence and the tenacity of the Leader of the Opposition. He will go anywhere, see anyone, say anything to anyone to try to get support. This is best reflected by the September edition of that august journal Talk to the animals. Some members opposite may not be aware of this journal, but they can purchase it for $3.95 or if in New Zealand they can purchase it for $5.95 including GST-but that is a separate issue. In the September issue of Talk to the animals the cover story is on the Leader of the Opposition: 'Alexander Downer on why dogs are good for you'. The heading to the story reads 'Doggone-if it isn't the Downers!' In this September edition of Talk to the animals you can read all about it: 'You can meet federal opposition leader Alexander Downer and his companionable canine Charlie'. It is often said by serious pet owners that like the master the dog and like the dog the master. In other words, the pet takes on the attributes of the master and the master takes on the attributes of the pet. In the course of this cover story, there is an interesting quote from a family member about canine Charlie, and it sums up the way that members on this side currently view the Leader of the Opposition. It reads: We love him a lot. We play games with him-we run and chase him, and when he's in the mood he bounces all over the place. He's lots of fun. He certainly is lots of fun. He is an absolute figure of fun. But there is a serious point here. I am sure that the Leader of the Opposition would not have entered into this interview without wanting to a send a very serious message to the community, in particular to his colleagues. We know, because of the nickname of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) given to him by the former member for Kooyong and made public by the Premier of Victoria, that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has a serious interest in these matters. Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I have the sad duty to report to the House the death of Ms Jacinta Watson of Coopers Plains in my electorate. Jacinta was killed on Saturday, 10 September because of an accident that occurred at the Greenbank army range during her participation in an army reserve training camp held that weekend. Jacinta had been in the army reserve for a couple of years and was participating in some practice Greenbank army range. Jacinta's death is an enormous tragedy and has, of course, had a profound impact on her husband and her family. Our hearts go out to Andrew, Jacinta's husband of 21 months; her parents, Stan and Gina Otuszewski of Coopers Plains in my electorate; and her sisters, Marissa and Chantal. This death is an enormous tragedy. It was an accident-an accident that we hope will never be repeated. I express my sincere personal sympathies, and I am sure the sympathies of all members of this House, to Jacinta's husband, family, many friends and work colleagues, and her army reserve friends who were all devastated by this tragedy. I understand that the army has established a board of inquiry which will investigate the circumstances of this accident and report to the Department of Defence, and most likely to the minister, on the cause of this accident. It is my sincere hope and wish that, if there were situations that led to this accident that could have been prevented, we will ensure that in future all procedures will be corrected so that such an accident should not occur again. It is important we ensure that when our young people participate in the army reserve, which is something we encourage and want so many of our young people to do so they can participate in the training towards the defence of this country, they can be protected from accidents of this nature. It is important that the parents of those people who are participating in this training can be assured that the Department of Defence and the army will take all such steps as they can to avoid any repeat incidents. The reason I am particularly concerned about making this speech is that it is the second accident in the past 18 months resulting in the death of someone on a training weekend. It is something I hope we can avoid happening in the future. Jacinta was a wonderful person. She was a vibrant, attractive and energetic young woman who tackled every challenge that was placed before her. She was much loved by all of her family, by her friends, by her work colleagues in the Queensland Department of Employment, Education and Training and by everyfiring at the one who ever met her. It was my sad duty to attend her funeral at St David's Anglican Church at Chelmer last Wednesday and to share in the grief of all of her family and friends who were gathered there. The commitment I wish to make to her family, to her parents and to her husband is that to the utmost of my ability I will try to ensure that the full circumstances of this accident are investigated and that wherever possible we take steps to make sure that no similar accident should ever occur again. Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Title: QLD SA WA TAS NT ACT
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The basis in Malaysian law for consideration of an extradition request by Australia was as follows. Malaysia recently adopted a new Extradition Act (Extradition Act 1992, No. 479 of 1992). Under section 3 of that Act it was open to Malaysian authorities to consider favourably an extradition request made by Australia. Moreover, Malaysian authorities did in fact treat the extradition request by Australia as received by them and given consideration under the Act. Extradition requests are frequently made where there is a discretion in the Requested State whether or not to grant extradition. For example, Australia's recent extradition treaties provide a discretion respect to the surrender of nationals of the Requestmeals ed State. Nonetheless, requests are frequently made by and to Australia for the surrender of nationals, and such requests are frequently granted. In the case of Prince Raja Kamarul Bahrin Shah, Malaysia has discretion whether or not to grant extradition both because there was no treaty obligation to extradite and because the Extradition Act of Malaysia expressly preserved a discretion in the case of nationals. However countries frequently exercise a discretion to extradite even when no obligation exists to do so. Malaysia had previously granted extradition requests made by Australia. (2) I note that this part of the question is directed to assistance in relation to the children who were not, of course, the subject of the extradition request. I am advised that, under the Overseas Custody (Child Removal) Scheme, financial assistance may be provided in hardship cases to assist a parent to institute legal proceedings overseas for recovery of his or her children removed from Australia, or detained overseas, by the other parent. An applicant has to show there is a reasonable chance of securing the return of the child or children to Australia. If an applicant is unable to afford the cost of an opinion from an overseas practitioner on the likely prospects of success of proceedings in a court, assistance may be granted to enable the applicant to obtain such opinion. I am further advised that as a special measure on an act of grace basis, approval was given to Mrs the Gillespie's solicitors for limited funding to allow an opinion to be obtained, whilst material on hardship could be considered. Particulars of the payment made were given in my answer to Question No. 902, and there was a reasonable basis, in pursuance of the Scheme, for the payment to be made. No other funds were made available by the Commonwealth to seek the return of the children. Rural Adjustment Scheme (Question No. 1425) Mr Tuckey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 25 August 1994: Have any unused funds from the operation of the Rural Adjustment Scheme in Western Australia been returned to the Commonwealth between 199091 and 1993-94. Mr Beddall-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: In regard to the RAS 1988 and RAS 1992 schemes; no unused funds in Western Australia have been returned to the Commonwealth between 1990-91 and 1993-94. Western Australia have made repayments of pre1985 rural reconstruction and adjustment schemes funds to the Commonwealth. These funds represent half-yearly repayments of principal and interest from loans made under those earlier schemes. Between I July 1990 and 15 January 1994, $22,748,934.15 was repaid. On 15 January 1994, a further amount of $20,4447,166.96 was paid in full settlement of the State's liability in respect to the Rural Adjustment Scheme; and $2,663,259.25 in full settlement in respect of the Rural Reconstruction Scheme and the Marginal Dairy Adjustment Scheme. Pensioners: Unrealised Capital Gains (Question No. 1444) Mr Slipper asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 August 1994: With respect to any inquiry instigated by him or his Department into ramifications of unrealised capital gains for pensioners, how many submissions (a) have been received by the committee conducting the inquiry from the electoral divisions of (i) Fisher, (ii) Wide Bay and (iii) Fairfax and (b) from the electoral divisions of (i) Fisher, (ii) Wide Bay and (iii) Fairfax were rejected for late arrival or other reasons. Mr Baldwin-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) The review of the pensions income and assets tests was announced in October 1993 to examine perceived problems with the income and assets tests including the issue of unrealised capital gains. An external consultant to undertake this review was appointed in February 1994. At 26 August 1994, the total number of submissions received from the following electoral divisions were: (i) Fisher, 38; (ii) Wide Bay, 23; and (iii) Fairfax, 49. Of these submissions, the number that mentioned either unrealised capital gains, managed investments or shares were: (i) Fisher, 24; (ii) Wide Bay, 13; and (iii) Fairfax, 16. (b) No submission has been rejected from either (i) Fisher, (ii) Wide Bay, (iii) Fairfax or any other electoral division. The cut-off date for submissions to be included in the consultant's Discussion Paper 'Questions of Balance' was 18 April 1994. Submissions received subsequent to that date and prior to 9 September 1994 will be taken into account in the preparation of the consultant's final report due in October 1994.
